prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Polarization C36-3-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Polarization observations toward five protostellr cores (Imaging up to 10 % polarized emission)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a polarization project. In Cycle 3, only TDM mode is allowed to select for the correlator setting.

Requested angular resolution (achieved by the C36-3 configuration) was determined by a balance between (i) higher angular resolution as possible to spatially resolve developed circumstellar disk (~a few x 100AU; at least requires 0.5" resolution for all the seven sources), (ii) enough polarized flux within the beam to obtain good quality of polarization images toward all sources as described above, and (iii) able to image relatively extended emission (~4" toward protostellar cores) observed with the previous SMA observations (listed in Table 2). Requested configuration is the best choice to satisfy all three conditions.
Note that this is polarization observations. Due to the off-axis instrumental polarization, source size, which show 1/3 of the primary beam size (~7.6" at the observing frequency) can be securely calibrated. Based on our previous SMA experiments (Table 1 and 2), we expect that all the protostellar cores can satisfy this condition.
Selected sources are all sit in the same filament. However the typical source separation in OMC-3 is ~17", which is larger than 1/2 primary beam size at Band6. Hence the proposed sources have enough separation to consider as isolated sources.

The polarized flux was estimated from our previous SMA continuum experiments at 345 GHz (Takahashi et al. 2013) assuming with the 3% polarization percentage (measured toward one of the targets, MMS6 using CARMA; Hull et al. 2013), dust emissivity index of beta=1.5, and scaling with the sources size obtained with the SMA and the ALMA beam (0.5") assuming with uniform flux distributions within the sources. Estimated fluxes at 265 GHz are listed in Table 2.
This group includes sample of protostellar cores. We aim to image up to ~10% level of polarized emission with respect to their polarized peak flux toward all the sources in this group. In order to obtain same noise level among our targets, the requested rms noise was justified from the expected polarized flux toward MMS2, which show the smallest expected polarization flux among all the five sources in this group.

Proposed Band 6 continuum frequency (rest frequency of 265 GHz) is optimized by the balance between the expected continuum fluxes (Table 2) and the receiver performance at the observing frequencies. Comparing the Band 6 standard observing frequency, we are able to perform proposed observation described in this science goal by 36% more efficient (The number was estimated from the time estimator and includes calibration time).
Scientifically, if we consider the dust emissivity index (beta) of greater than 1 (usually beta~2.0 in ISM), dust emission will tend to be optically thick with increasing frequency. Using the requested frequency instead of the Band 7 standard frequency (frequency difference factor of 1.3) will help us to obtain dust image in the optically more thin frequency regime (~36% better than Ban7 case if beta=2 is assumed). This may be critical for some of our bright sources.
Finally, Band 6 observations, which has more relaxed observing condition compared to Band 7, would give us more chances to perform the observations. This would help the observatory to operate the telescope more efficient.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Polarization C36-3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Polarization observations toward two prestellar cores (Imaging up to 30 % polarized emission)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a polarization project. In Cycle 3, only TDM mode is allowed to select for the correlator setting.

Requested angular resolution (achieved by C36-3 configuration) was determined by a balance between (i) higher angular resolution as possible to spatially resolve developed circumstellar disk (~a few x 100 AU; at least requires 0.5" resolution for all the seven sources), (ii) enough polarized flux within the beam to obtain good quality of polarization images toward all sources as described above, and (iii) able to image relatively extended emission observed with the previous SMA observations (Table 2). Requested configuration is the best choice to satisfy all three conditions.
Note that this is polarization observations. Due to the off-axis instrumental polarization, source size of the 1/3 of the primary beam size (~7.6") can be securely calibrated. Based on our previous SMA experiments, MMS3 and MMS4 are more extended than the maximum detectable size, however the central part of the core (denoted by the red dashed circles in Figure 1B zoomed images) can be properly calibrated, and those areas are most important part to look to answer our science goals described in the proposal.
Selected sources are all sit in the same filament. However the typical source separation in OMC-3 is ~17", which is larger than 1/2 primary beam size at Band 6. Hence, the proposed source have enough separation to consider isolated sources.

The expected polarized flux was estimated from our previous SMA continuum experiments at 345 GHz (Takahashi et al. 2013) assuming with the 3% polarization percentage (measured toward one of the targets, MMS6 using CARMA; Hull et al. 2013), dust emissivity index of beta=1.5, and scaling with the source sizes obtained with SMA and the ALMA beam size (0.5") assuming with the uniform flux distributions within the sources. Estimated fluxes at 265 GHz are listed in Table 2.
This group includes sample of prestellar cores. We aim to image up to ~30% level of polarized emission with respect to their polarized peak flux (listed in Table 2). In order to obtain same noise level among our target in this group, the request rms noise was justified from the expected polarized flux toward MMS3, which show the smallest expeced polarization flux among two prestellar sources.
Same reason what we described in 1st science goal.

We observe molecular outflows in CO and SiO. Lowest outflow velocity we expect to see from the youngest protostellar cores are a few km/s (e.g., Machida et al. 2007; outflow from the first core). In order to spectrally resolve those outflow, we request a velocity resolution of ~0.4km/s.
We also observe dense gas associated with core, envelope, and disk in C18O and N2D+. Since, some of our candidates are prestellar, we may see thermal gas motion (~0.2 km/s assuming the 10 K gas). In order to spectrally resolve it with enough number of channels, we request the highest frequency resolution in Band 6 with 2 channel averaging. (~0.04 km/s).

Same angular resolution achieved with the polarization observations, ~0.5", (described in 1st and 2nd science goals) is required for this science goal in order to make direct spatial comparison between line and polarization images. we expect that the emission from the core, envelope, and outflow are extended (e.g., Takahashi et al. 2006; Takahashi et al. 2008). Hence, we also request the ACA observations to recover the extended emission. On the other hand, most important information we will would like to obtain is spatial and velocity structures in the central a few x 1000 AU scale, which can be covered by Band 6 single field. Hence, no mosaic observations will be needed.

Our line observations are justified from the previous SMA CO observations toward MMS6, which has the most compact known outflow among the targets (Takahashi et al. 2012b). Although SMA observations are obtained in J=3-2, we expect to see similar or higher intensity in J=2-1 (results from RADEX assuming conditions for outflow gas). In order to search for unknown compact outflow possibly associated with the prestellar candidates, we request approximately factor of 10 better sensitivity ALMA observations compared to previous SMA observations (0.14 Jy/beam km/s with 0.82"x0.64" resolution). Adopting the beam size difference between SMA and ALMA and factor of 10 better sensitivity, we request the 1 sigma noise level of 7 mJy/beam km/s. The velocity resolution of ~0.367km/s (selected for BB1 in the spectral setup tab) was assumed.
Assuming this, we expect to have 1 sigma noise level of ~19mJy/beam km/s for BB4 (for C18O observations). Assuming 5 sigma detection in C18O, the minimum detectable mass is estimated to be 4.3e-06 Mo assuming the LTE condition. This number is more than enough to detect C18O emission likely associated with IM prestellar and protostellar cores.

As described above, thermal gas motion (velocity dispersion of ~0.2 km/s) might be seen toward prestellar candidates. In order to spectrally resolve those components, we request the highest frequency resolution in FDM averagin with 2 channels.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Polarization C36-8
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Long baseline experiment toward MMS 6 (The brigtest continuum sources among seven sources, follow up with high-angular resolution to see the internal disk)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a polarization project. In Cycle 3, only TDM mode is allowed to select for the correlator setting.

Requested angular resolution (achived by the C36-8 configuration) was determined by a balance between (i) the highest angular resolution as possible to spatially resolve undevelopped cirucumstellr disk (~a few x 10 AU), (ii) enough polarized flux within the beam to obtain good quality of polarization image, and (iii) able to detect possibly extended structures obtained with the SMA (~0.3"x0.3"; called MMS6-compact in Takahashi et al. 2012). Requested configuration is the best configuration to satisfy all the three conditions.

Compact SMA continuum obtained at 345 GHz show flux density of 1.0 Jy within 0.3"x0.3" (Takahashi et al. 2012). Adopting the 3% polarization percentage (Hull et al. 2013), dust emissivity spectral index (beta=0.93; Takahashi et al. 2009), and scaling with the SMA source size (0.3) and ALMA (0.03") assuming with the uniform flux distribution within the structure, lower limit of the polarized flux at 265 GHz is estimated to be ~230 uJy/beam within the 0.03" ALMA beam. We aim to image up to ~10 % level of polarized emission from this experiment, so that the rms noise level of 23 uJy/beam is required.
Same reasons described in the first science goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Understanding the magnetic field on size scales smaller than a core (<0.05 pc) is crucial to see how the magnetic field is responsible for setting initial conditions of star-formation.
We propose polarization and molecular line observations toward candidates of intermediate-mass prestellar and protostellar cores in OMC-3, where is the nearest ideal laboratory for studying the magnetically regulated core-collapse process.
Proposed polarization observations will spatially resolve the polarization distribution and we aim to measure the polarization degree down to 200 AU scale for all the targets, and down to 12 AU for the brightest and youngest protostellar source found in OMC-3. Proposed line observations will directly image core internal structures such as pseudo disk, circumstellar disk, and root of the outflow, and reveal their kinematic structures with the same angular resolution obtained for polarization images. The obtained results will be compared and iterated with theoretical models (MHD simulations) optimized specifically for our targets, and finally study how the magnetic field changes with respect to the evolutionary stages of cores.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: I have a high-priority Cycle 2 proposal (2013.1.00231.S), which hasn't observed yet at the time of submitting this Cycle 3 proposal. SG-1 and SG-2 of our Cycle 3 proposal includes similar science goals, which were described in the Cycle 2 proposal. Therefore, if those observations will be completed by the end of Cycle 2, we are able to skip SG-1 and SG-2. SG-3 and SG-4 are newly proposed observations, which are the complemental data. Both cycle 2 and 3 project will deliver independent new restuls. Combination will be able to trace how B fields changes from core to disk scale.
